docs.lead_paragraph: With time running out, a 180-nation conference struggling to repair a shattered consensus on limiting world population growth was still divided today over issues ranging from abortion and family planning to sex education in schools. The conference is supposed to present an updated action plan to a special session of the United Nations General Assembly on Wednesday. But the talks adjourned late tonight with no agreement except that the parties would continue discussions in parallel with that General Assembly debate.

headline.main: U.N. Meeting Splits Sharply On Limiting Population

docs.abstract: United Nations conference on implementing Cairo strategy for limiting world population growth struggles to repair shattered consensus as relatively small number of conservative Roman Catholic and Muslim developing nations, with strong support from Vatican, block final accord on key issues; paying for program is also problematic, with industrialized world far in arrears and spending by developing nations also lagging; program seeks to prevent world population, now at around 6 billion, from rising above 9.8 billion by 2050 by trying to improve social status, education and health of young women and men to spur them to limit family size (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A June 26 news article described the unnecessary suffering of children when states fail to provide adequate reimbursement to dentists under Medicaid. I write to call attention to similar shortsightedness in the failure to provide reimbursement for the treatment of periodontal disease of pregnant women.

headline.main: Medicare Drugs: Let the Wealthy Pay

docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Beatrice A Murray scores Medicaid for not covering treatment of periodontal disease of pregnant women; cites evidence linking premature births to mothers with untreated periodontal disease

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Bill Bradley is encouraged that contemporary high school seniors, in contrast to high school seniors of 20 years ago, are ''more likely to believe in God'' (column, June 27). This greater likelihood of belief in God among today's students, along with the lesser likelihoods of drug- and alcohol-taking and teen-age pregnancy, causes Mr. Bradley to proclaim that ''our children are basically good children.''

headline.main: Politics Can Use Some Compassion; Faith and Goodness

docs.abstract: Letter from Calvin Cahan prompted by June 27 article on Bill Bradley; comments on Bradley's statements about today's youth; drawing
